title: 114_s2182
content:
The "Cut, Cap, and Balance Act of 2015" is also known as the "Cut" Act. It modifies the Congressional Budget Act by adding spending limits. The "Cut, Cap, and Balance Act of 2015" sets spending limits for fiscal year 2016 to prevent exceeding specified budget authority and outlays. Adjustments can be made by the House or Senate Committee on the Budget for enforcement purposes. The House or Senate Committee on the Budget may adjust spending limits for enforcement purposes based on new budget authority in a measure, with subsequent revisions to suballocations by the House or Senate Committee on Appropriations. The House or Senate Committee on Appropriations may adjust spending limits based on new budget authority in a measure, with revised suballocations as needed. For appropriations for fiscal year 2016 related to Overseas Contingency Operations/Global War on Terrorism, allowable adjustments shall not exceed $58,000,000,000 in budget authority. SEC. 317 of the bill sets limits on total spending in the House of Representatives and the Senate, with exemptions for certain functions like Social Security, Medicare, Veterans Benefits, Net Interest, and Military personnel accounts. SEC. 102 enforces spending caps through sequestration. SEC. 102 enforces spending caps through sequestration under Title III of the Congressional Budget Act of 1974. Implementation of sequesters shall be done separately for discretionary and direct spending, following specific sections of the Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985. Military personnel accounts, TRICARE for Life, Medicare, military retirement, and Social Security are exempt from certain provisions. The Balanced Budget and Control Act of 1985 exempts certain payments from sequestration, including military personnel accounts, TRICARE for Life, Medicare, military retirement, Social Security, veterans, net interest, and discretionary appropriations. The provisions of section 258A of the same Act apply to the consideration in the House of Representatives and the Senate after a sequestration report is issued by the Director of the Office of Management and Budget. The Office of Management and Budget issues a sequestration report, and the provisions of section 258A of the Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985 apply to the consideration in the House of Representatives and the Senate of a bill or joint resolution to override the order. It is not in order to consider a bill or joint resolution that alters a sequestration order unless certified by the chair of the House or Senate Committee on the Budget. In the House of Representatives or Senate, it is not allowed to consider a bill that changes a sequestration order unless certified by the chair of the House or Senate Committee on the Budget. SEC. 201 of TITLE II--CAP limits total spending by amending definitions in the Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985. It also adds a definition for GDP. Additionally, SEC. 319 of Title III of the Congressional Budget Act of 1974 enforces GDP outlay limits. The term 'GDP outlay limit' is defined as an amount based on projected GDP for each fiscal year, with specific percentages set for each year from 2016 to 2025. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget determines these limits. The GDP outlay limit percentages are set at 18 percent for fiscal years 2021 to 2025. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget establishes the GDP outlay limit in the President's budget. Sequestration to enforce this section will be carried out according to the Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985. Section 255 of the Balanced Budget and Control Act of 1985 does not apply to this section. Sequestration to enforce the GDP outlay limit percentages set at 18 percent for fiscal years 2021 to 2025 will be implemented according to the Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985. Certain programs such as military personnel accounts, TRICARE for Life, Medicare, military retirement, Social Security, veterans, and net interest are exempt from sequestration. SEC. 320 of the Congressional Budget Act of 1974 prohibits considering any legislation that would exceed the current GDP outlay limits. TITLE III--BALANCE

SEC. 301. REQUIREMENT FOR A BALANCED BUDGET AMENDMENT TO BE SUBMITTED TO STATES. The Secretary of the Treasury cannot borrow more money unless a balanced budget amendment to the Constitution is proposed, which includes limits on spending and requires a \2/3\ vote for tax increases. It is not allowed for any bill to be considered that would increase borrowing authority until the balanced budget amendment is proposed. The Secretary of the Treasury cannot borrow more money without a balanced budget amendment to the Constitution being proposed, which includes spending limits and tax increase requirements. No bill can be considered to increase borrowing authority until the balanced budget amendment is proposed.
